title: @Riot: Why was Kat originally made AP?
body: This question is (probably) best directed at any OGs from the very beginning stages of the game's creation. I'm curious what led to her being a magician given that she uses daggers to cut through her foes.

replies.body: She was released at a time where the design of the game was "abilities increase with ability power, attacks increase with attack damage" with only a few exceptions. I think she actually was usually played as AD on release as her passive was a weird active with auto steroids instead of the reset she's known for.

This is pretty much it from my understanding (I wasn't at Riot at the time). Abilities that weren't attack replacements scaling with AD instead of AP wasn't particularly a thing for the first 40 champs during beta. Pantheon, just after launch, was the first really big exception to that.  

If we were making Kat today I think it's highly likely she'd scale with AD primarily and do mainly physical damage. There's a high cost to converting her to that though, in terms of existing playstyle disrupted and built up attachment to AP Kat. We don't have any plans to retrofit her kit like that as a result.
I know it may not make sense with Zed, but Kat's a teleporting assassin with bouncing blades. I think she's magical enough to be AP.
This.
I've always thought AP assassins are generally healthier anyway. It just means you don't wind up with a Zed type scenario where they can outburst squishies and outduel many tankier champs.

> I've always thought AP assassins are generally healthier anyway. It just means you don't wind up with a Zed type scenario where they can outburst squishies and outduel many tankier champs.

For a reset-assassin like Katarina, I disagree. Giving her sustained damage at the cost of reducing her burst would give her wiggle room between 'useless' and '1v5 machine' because a kill doesn't reset 95% of her damage (which is also AoE).
Alternatively it just creates scenarios where Kat burst tanks or bruisers for ~50% of their HP then DPSes them down before resetting onto an ADC. There's definitely pros and cons to each.

If she bursts an adc for 2/3 of their health and dps's down the rest, then she can probably only burst less than 1/4 of a tank's health. Her numbers could definitely be balanced to where she would lose most straight fights with anything that isn't squishy.
If she can only burst ADCs for 2/3rds of their HP then playing her over any other control mage or assassin is questionable because she's not actually doing that much.
